title: ben stokes to play for england against india days after being cleared of affray
story: On Tuesday, Stokes was found not guilty of affray following a fight outside a nightclub in the Clifton area of Bristol almost 11 months ago.Discussing Curran, who put in a man-of-the-match performance at Edgbaston, Root said it was "about us as a squad performing collectively for five games"."On this occasion he's unfortunate to miss out," Root added, "but what he's done so far has been nothing short of high class."

title: danny cipriani to face rugby football union disciplinary hearing
story: "I have this afternoon taken the decision to charge Danny Cipriani."The rugby union player's hearing will take place in front an independent disciplinary panel next week with the date, time and panel members to be confirmed.Cipriani pleaded guilty to common assault and resisting arrest at Jersey Magistrates' Court on Wednesday.Samantha Morris, prosecuting, said the altercation broke out when a doorman stopped Cipriani from walking out of the bar in St Helier with two drinks.The doorman then called police when Cipriani became "physically aggressive".Cipriani has been ordered to pay &#163250 compensation to the officer on top of the &#1631,500 he was handed for resisting arrest and the &#163500 for assault.Gloucester chief executive Stephen Vaughan says Cipriani "will receive our full support".Cipriani's latest episode follows a poor disciplinary record that includes previous court appearances for drink-driving.The rugby player released a statement apologising after he was fined, in which he said: "I want to start with a heartfelt apology."To my club, teammates, supporters and most importantly the police.

title: elon musk reveals excruciating year for tesla and says worst yet to come for himself
story: Mr Musk, who is dating Canadian singer Grimes, 30, last week caused havoc in the markets after tweeting, in the middle of the night, that he hoped to take the publicly traded company private.That tweet, with the fateful words "funding secured", kicked off a federal investigation as it could be seen as manipulating the marketplace and it turns out the Saudi government had spoken to him about funding but had parted with no cash yet.His board has told him to focus on production rather than Twitter, especially after he called a cave diver rescuing the Thai football team a "paedo guy". Known for being extremely ambitious with his ideas, the South African has been one of Silicon Valley's most influential entrepreneurs for two decades.But the limelight has taken its toll, with Mr Musk admitting he works 120 hour weeks and has not taken more than a week off since 2001 - when he had malaria.He also emotionally revealed he spent his entire 47th birthday on 28 June at work."All night - no friends, nothing," he said.Two days after that he was best man at his brother Kimbal Musk's wedding in Catalonia, where he flew from the factory to arrive two hours before the ceremony.He said he flew straight back after the wedding to Tesla's headquarters to make good on his promise to get those Model 3s out - something he eventually achieved on 1 July."I thought the worst of it was over - I thought it was," he said."The worst is over from a Tesla operational standpoint."But from a personal pain standpoint, the worst is yet to come."Mr Musk said he blames his stress on short-sellers who bet Tesla's shares will lose value if it goes private.He said he is bracing for "at least a few months of extreme torture from the short-sellers, who are desperately pushing a narrative that will possibly result in Tesla's destruction".On short-sellers, he said: "They're not dumb guys, but they're not supersmart. They're OK. They're smartish." Mr Musk admitted to taking the sleeping pill Ambien, saying: "It is often a choice of no sleep or Ambien."However, some board members have said it does not help him sleep but contributes to his late-night Twitter sessions, which often get him in trouble.Mr Musk said, there is an ongoing search to find a deputy to help him, but "to the best of my knowledge" it is not active at the moment.But, people familiar with the search said it escalated after Mr Musk's tweets about taking the company private and the cave diver.

title: house of fraser cancels online orders and offers refunds
story: Most of the &#16390m Mr Ashley paid for the store will be used by the administrator to pay banks and bondholders. There will be very little left for suppliers, like Tommy Hilfiger, Topshop and Mango.A message posted on the HoF's website said: "We're working hard to makes some improvements to the website. Don't worry, we will be back up and running as soon as possible."And on Facebook it said: "We have taken the decision to cancel and refund all orders that have not already been sent to customers."We didn't take this decision lightly, but since we cannot give our customers clear assurances of when their orders will be delivered, we believe cancellation is the best option."All customers affected will receive an email about the cancellation and refund in the next couple of days."Please accept our apologies for any inconvenience caused and thank you from everyone at House of Fraser for your patience at this time."The announcement was met with dismay by some customers who had placed orders online, some several days ago.

title: smartphone screens found to be more than three times dirtier than a toilet seat
story: Insurance2go measured the dirtiest parts of the phones by counting the amount of colony-forming units per cm2.The units are used to measure the number of viable bacteria or fungal cells in a sample.The screens of the three handsets had a combined total of 254.9 colony-forming units per cm2, making them by the far the filthiest parts of the phones that were tested.This mean there was an average of 84.9 units on each screen.In contrast a toilet and flush was found to have just 24 units, while an office keyboard and mouse was found to have just five. The test found the back of the phones had an average of 30 units, the lock button had an average of 23.8 units, and the home button had an average of 10.6 units.The Google Pixel had 14.5 colony-forming units on its screen, another 14.5 on its lock, while 24 were found on the home button and 24 were on the back.The iPhone 6 had 40.4 units on its screen, 42.5 on the lock, another 42.5 on the back and 2.9 on the home button.Insurance2go has released the findings after Ofcom shed a light on the UK's smartphone addiction, with owners checking their handset every 12 minutes.Dr Shirin Lakhani of the skin clinic Elite Aesthetics said: "Our smartphones are a really big source of skin contamination and skin problems namely acne."Skin friction, heat and pressure to the skin all contribute to skin problems caused by smartphones." Gary Beeston, sales and marketing manager at Insurance2go, said: "Our phones are never far from our sides we take them everywhere with us."Therefore, it's inevitable that they'll pick up a few germs along the way."In our experiment we took the germs that are normally lurking on our phones invisibly, and placed them in ideal growing conditions to help people see the potential hidden germs."Perhaps we don't realise quite how infectious our phones can be considering we're holding them against our faces!

title: e cigarette users should allowed
story: NewsE-cigarette users should be allowed to vape in offices and on trains and buses to help smokers quit say MPsBut public health experts have challenged the claims with one saying the report relies solely on accounts by "e-cig champions"Share&nbsp&nbspCommentsByNicola BartlettPolitical Correspondent09:23, 17 AUG 2018NewsIt comes days after scientists warned that the perception that e-cigarettes are safe should be treated with caution (Image: REUTERS)Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailRules around e-cigarettes should be relaxed to help accelerate already declining smoking rates, MPs have said. A key committee has said that relaxing laws that stop people from vaping in offices and on trains could reduce deaths from smoking. The report by the Science and Technology Committee (STC) argues that vaping is less harmful than smoking cigarettes and that they should not be treated the same. They have called for an urgent review to make it easier for e-cigarettes to be made available on prescription, wider debate on vaping in public spaces, and greater freedom for the industry to advertise the devices as a less harmful option for smokers. But some public health experts have challenged the claims with one saying the report relies solely on accounts by e-cig champions. The report's release comes days after scientists warned that the perception that e-cigarettes are safe should be treated with caution.  Research led by the University of Birmingham found the vapourised e-liquid fluid in e-cigarettes has a similar effect on the lungs and body that is seen in regular cigarette smokers and patients with chronic lung disease. The Government has said it will carefully consider the evidence and recommendations made by the STC. Norman Lamb, the committee's chairman, told the : “The blunt fact is that 79,000 people in England still die of smoking every year, which is sort of unconscionable, particularly when we know there is the means by which we can reduce the death toll. He said that current policy and regulations do not sufficiently reflect the lesser harm posed by e-cigarettes than their conventional alternatives. Businesses, transport providers and public places should stop viewing conventional and e-cigarettes as one and the same, he said. There is no public health rationale for doing so. Concerns that e-cigarettes could be a gateway to conventional smoking, including for young non-smokers, have not materialised. If used correctly, e-cigarettes could be a key weapon in the NHS stop-smoking arsenal.  Public Health England (PHE) has estimated that e-cigarettes are at least 95% less harmful than smoking.  While uncertainties remain about the long-term health impact of the devices, they present an opportunity to significantly accelerate already declining smoking rates, the committee of MPs said. Mr Lamb said: Medically licensed e-cigarettes would make it easier for doctors to discuss and recommend them as a stop smoking tool to aid those quitting smoking. The approval systems for prescribing these products must be urgently reviewed. The report also called for limits on refill strengths and tank sizes, which may put off heavy smokers looking for a strong nicotine hit, to be reviewed. Meanwhile, NHS England's default policy should be that e-cigarettes are permitted on mental health units, to address the stubbornly high levels of smoking among people with mental health conditions, the report said. Around 2.9 million people in the UK are currently using e-cigarettes, with an estimated 470,000 using them as an aid to stop smoking, according to the report. Duncan Selbie, chief executive of PHE, said: E-cigarettes are not without harm but are way safer than the harms of tobacco. This is about comparing e-cigarettes to normal cigarettes, not fresh air. The UK leads the world in harm reduction from tobacco and there is no evidence that they are acting as a gateway into smoking for young people. Alison Cook, director of policy at the British Lung Foundation (BLF), said the report provides clarity on the potential of the devices.  The choice to switch to e-cigarettes must be made easier, she added. The report comes days after a Professor David Thickett, of the University of Birmingham's Institute of Inflammation and Ageing, warned the public must be aware that these devices are not harmless. He led a study published in the journal Thorax on Tuesday that e-cigarette vapour boosts the production of inflammatory chemicals and disables key protective cells in the lungs. He said: It has been suggested electronic cigarettes are safer than traditional cigarettes, and this narrative is increasingly supported by tobacco companies that have established research institutes devoted to generating supportive data. Reacting to the STC's report Simon Capewell, Professor in Public Health and Policy from Liverpool University, told the Daily Mail: The committee has concentrated solely on experts who are e-cig champions. More balanced reviews of the evidence by the World Health Organisation, (US) Food and Drug Administration have concluded that e-cigs are no better for quitting smoking than things like nicotine gum, patches or tablets. E-cigs in teens are a gateway to subsequent smoking lit cigarettes and e-cig vapour contains a large number of toxins which in time will obviously harm users, and bystanders. The STC's report also said an end to the ban on snus, an oral tobacco product which is illegal in the UK under EU regulations, should be considered after Brexit.

title: audi owner wins 10 month
story: NewsAudi owner wins 10-month compensation battle after £92k car damaged by loose road chippingsRobert Johnston successfully took a road resurfacing contractor to the small claims courtShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByAimi Redfern23:01, 16 AUG 2018Updated00:46, 17 AUG 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay nowGet daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA driver has won a lengthy 10-month battle after his new &pound92k Audi was damaged by loose road chippings. Robert Johnston successfully took a road resurfacing contractor to the small claims court after the firm refused to reimburse him for the damage. Mr Johnston's A6 was parked outside his business in Silverdale Road, Newcastle , last September when it was chipped by loose stones following the surface dressing of the road, the Stoke Sentinel reports. The 42-year-old repeatedly contacted both Staffordshire County Council, which is responsible for the road, and the firm contracted to carry out the work, Knutsford-based Road Management Services (RMS), with his concerns about the standard and safety of the surface.  RMS eventually wrote to Mr Johnston to say it had inspected the site and found 'no signs of loose aggregate' - and would therefore not offer him any compensation. Mr Johnston then launched a legal battle and, following a hearing at Stoke-on-Trent County Court, a judge ordered RMS to pay him &pound4,211.20 in compensation, plus &pound745 to cover his legal costs. The businessman, who owns Silverdale Motors, said: The court case was a dark cloud hanging over me. I was representing myself and it was quite a daunting experience. When the judge ruled in my favour I was really happy. It has been 10 months of hard work but it paid off. When you are right, you're right. The company has been negligent. Despite winning his legal battle, Mr Johnston remains concerned about the state of Silverdale Road.  The county council said if work on the road network was not up to standard, the contractor would have to remedy this at their own expense. Helen Fisher, cabinet member for Highways and Transport, said: “We have more than 6,000km of roads and the surface dressing programme plays a key role in reducing the risk of potholes.

title: aretha franklin showed whole world
story: NewsopinionAretha Franklin showed the whole world how it felt to be alive - and she always willFleet Street Fox whacks the volume up on the Queen of all our soulsShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByFleet Street FoxColumnist12:54, 17 AUG 2018Updated13:07, 17 AUG 2018NewsopinionGet daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailWhen someone famous dies, it is usual for writers to sum up their lives in an obituary that describes their wins and losses. But I'm not going to tell you about Aretha Franklin's failings. They don't matter to a single one of us, and they don't matter any more to those closest to her. Aretha reached. That's the only word I can find to describe how her life panned out, what she achieved and what she meant. She lost her mother at 10, was pregnant by a school friend at 11, a mother at 12 and again at 15, daughter to a perverted superstar preacher who ran drug-and-sex orgies, and wife to a pimp who beat her. Singer Sam Cooke, a friend of her father's, is thought to have had sex with a 12-year-old Aretha when he was 23. Etta James, who died six years ago, was in the same congregation and said: I can understand Aretha not wanting to talk about that . . . Who wants to admit that you’re praising the Lord at the 8 p.m. service and servicing some drop-dead gorgeous hunk of a singer an hour later? Today, it's called child abuse. It's abandonment, vulnerable girls, predatory men, the most troubled and turbulent background it's possible to imagine. Yet through it Aretha reached - in the period after her mother died, she learned to play the piano by ear.  She went on the gospel circuit with her father, had her first two children and signed her first record deal. She almost signed to Tamla's motown label, which worked wonders for Diana Ross but would have buried Aretha's talent. She did better at Columbia, but in 1966 signed to the soul label Atlantic and hit the heights.  In February 1967 she released first single I Never Loved A Man. The B-side was Do Right Woman, Do Right Man. The B-side. In April she released her version of Otis Redding's Respect and in the space of just 3 months she was a megastar.  She did all that by the time she was 25, and with two children. She did it with a crappy childhood, sexual exploitation, and at a time when women and black women in particular were segregated, sidelined, and dehumanised. She did it because she reached back into her life, found the love and the pain, and hauled it up like Jonah wrestling his whale. Listen to her quiet, sad, dignified request for men to treat her kindly, and ask yourself who else could perform the same feat.  Aretha became a star for the same reason as Elvis Presley - she reached across the race divide. But while Elvis made black music acceptable by being a sexy white boy, Aretha showed that black and white both hurt the same. There's not a woman on the planet who doesn't want a Do Right Man, and after listening to that song, no man who doesn't want to do better. She sold 75million records to people who were not born in a wooden shack, weren't raised by perverts, had no interest in Baptist gospel and who nevertheless felt at one with her. When I was a teenager, she whispered in my ear about unrequited love. When I was a woman, she and I belted out songs about freedom and joy. When I fell in love we sang of our sweet, sweet baby, and when I was heartbroken, she raged with me about The House That Jack Built. And she winked at me and nodded when I changed our lyrics to demand he never came back. She was us. They were all our songs. And if she reached through it all, then we knew we could find the strength to do the same.  There is a moment in every one of her songs where you think she's given it all she can. Then she takes a breath, reaches, and finds some more. I don't know whether it's her diaphragm, her voice, or just plain magic but it elevates whoever hears it. Douglas Adams described Mark Knopfler as a man capable of making his guitar hoot and sing like angels on a Saturday night said there was a moment in every Dire Straits song where it is possible to fly. Well, Aretha sings like the angels' jaded, yet hopeful barmaid, and there is a point in every song where she lifts the weight of the world from everyone's shoulders. Her loved ones said she never sought help for her demons, never truly dealt with her drinking, gorging, and trips to mental clinics. Instead she went on stage. Perhaps if she had the help she deserved she would not have helped the rest of us realise we were not alone. She kept back the careers of her sisters, raged at friends, threw strops that would have embarrassed Henry VIII, but I don't care that she must have been hell to live with. With her, the rest of us had heaven on Earth.  She played piano like it was a percussion instrument. She arranged many of her own songs, and had the same natural talent for music that the rest of us do for breathing. But there's one story that tells you more about her than anything else.  In 1998 she was at the Grammys to perform her Blues Brothers version of Think, with John Belushi and Dan Aykroyd. Her friend Luciano Pavarotti was due to perform Nessun Dorma, and despite rehearsing it perfectly he called in 30 minutes after the show began to say he had a cold and could no longer sing.  Aretha was asked to fill the gap, perhaps do one of her signature tracks. She asked instead to hear Pavarotti's rehearsal. Producer Ken Ehrlich said: In those days we had a boombox with a cassette. And I brought it to her and played it for her. When she heard it, she said, ‘Yeah, I can do this'. She went out on stage, for a live, worldwide broadcast, with an orchestra she'd not practised with, a choir she didn't know and a nervous conductor, and sang, in Italian, one of the most iconic and powerful songs in the world. One minute in, she reaches. Then reaches again, and again, and you're wowed, and somehow she reaches twice more and hits the final high note. Those final words, translated, are: At dawn, I will win. I will win, I will win!  At 16 Aretha had toured with Martin Luther King, and 10 years later sang at his funeral. She was rightly honoured and lauded throughout her later life, in 1987 she became the first woman inducted into the Rock'n'Roll Hall of Fame, and she even had an asteroid named after her. She's been called the greatest singer of all time, the voice of the civil rights movement, and much else besides. She was a spendthrift, a diva, and had a mink coat that she loved so much it used to have its own seat. Through it all, she remained an insecure little girl who thought she wasn't good enough. Still she reached for something more. More food, more drink, more men, more, more, more than this. And that's where her magic lay - the ability to show hope amid pain, to see potential in a poverty of experience. That is, after all, the thing that makes us human. We can rise, and when her voice soars it makes you feel that you have, and you can. If that's not soul, I don't know what is. In 2015 at a ceremony honouring songwriter Carol King, Aretha performed Natural Woman. She thumped those piano keys like they were in trouble, her voice hit the song at full speed, and Barack Obama wept 20 seconds after she'd opened her mouth. Halfway through, she stands up and reaches for a high note as the auditorium gives her a standing ovation. She throws that mink coat to the floor, and finds more. She goes on, and up, and up, and there's nothing the audience can do but clap harder. She was a natural woman. She made us feel what it was like to be her, and to be us, and to be human. She showed us what soul was, and she'll never stop because that voice will never be silent. My daughter will grow up with Aretha in her ears, feeling that they two alone share a secret. You make us feel, Aretha. You always will.

title: bradley lowerys mum denies shes
story: NewsBradley Lowery's mum denies she's 'living luxury lifestyle on charity money' after being targeted by trollsGemma's son Bradley lost his fight against neuroblastoma last year at the age of six and The Bradley Lowery Foundation was set up in tribute to himShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByChris Knight12:00, 17 AUG 2018Updated12:31, 17 AUG 2018NewsBradley Lowery's mum has hit back at claims she's 'living a luxury lifestyle on charity money' (Image: Sunderland AFC)Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailBradley Lowery’s heartbroken mum has denied she's living a luxury lifestyle on charity money after being targeted by cruel trolls. The Bradley Foundation was set up to continue the legacy of the Sunderland superfan who lost his fight against neuroblastoma last year at the age of six.  In a passionate Facebook post on Thursday afternoon, the charity defended itself against social media claims relating to the misuse of funds raised in Bradley’s name, reports Chronicle Live .  One highlighted comment suggested the Lowery family were enjoying a “luxury lifestyle” and suggested “the truth will be out soon”.  Bradley's mum Gemma hit back at the accusations and said all the money raised in her son's name was given to the foundation. She said: “We have had a few people writing silly comments saying the charity money is not going to the charity. “Anybody in their right mind knows every penny donated to charity stays with the charity. Everything that was raised for Bradley, we donated it all. “I don’t think they realise everything that goes on behind the scenes. People don’t know we’re sometimes up till midnight messaging parents about treatment options. “It’s a shame we have to justify ourselves when we are working 16-17 hour days.”  The Foundation’s lengthy response also revealed the charity is in the process of its annual audit and the results will be published online. Gemma, from Blackhall Colliery, added: “We are getting punished because we have not published everything we do with the money. “They will be free for every single person to look at.” Lynn Murphy, head of communications and fundraising with the Foundation, confirmed the charity will not have a definitive figure on the money raised until the annual audit is completed.  The accounts will show funds was spent on four rounds of last-ditch rounds of immunotherapy treatment for Bradley in the last months of his life. Lynn said the Foundation received numerous trolling messages, but the accusation of a “luxury lifestyle” prompted the charity to respond. She added: “Cremating a child is not a life of luxury, it’s a life of torment and grief. Gemma’s emotional state at this time is not great - she should not have to put up with these messages. “We have had messages from every single one of the families we have worked with saying how sorry we are we have to go through this. “We thank everyone in the local community for their support. These comments are few and far between.

story: NewsBritain's Got Talent finalist Simonne Kerr murder accused appears in court after singer found dead in London flatDesmond Sylva, 40, was charged with the murder of the singer who shot to fame on BGT choir B PositiveShare&nbspByAdela Whittingham14:18, 17 AUG 2018Updated14:52, 17 AUG 2018NewsSimonne Kerr and son Kavele (Image: Collect Unknown)Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA man accused of murdering a Britain's Got Talent finalist has appeared in court. title: exclusive new research reveals britains
story: AdvertorialExclusive new research reveals Britain’s public toilets are vanishing at a staggering rate - and here’s whyWe've teamed up with Domestos to address the shortage of public facilities with the new Use Our Loos campaignShare&nbspByRichard Innes15:43, 16 AUG 2018Updated10:35, 17 AUG 2018AdvertorialBritain's public toilets are quickly disappearingGet daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThey have been a much-valued feature of British high streets for more than 160 years. But public loos are being wiped out at a staggering rate as councils struggle with government budget cuts. More than a QUARTER of public toilets have disappeared since the turn of the century, according to data obtained under Freedom of Information laws. According to the new information - supplied by council areas across the UK - the total number of public toilets across the country has dropped from 3,084 in 2000 to 2,290 in 2018. That is a fall of nearly 800. And authorities in Bolsover, North East Derbyshire, and Wokingham admitted they no longer had ANY council-run loos. In London, of the councils that provided information, the number of public loos was down from 197 in 2000 to just 132 today. The rest of England saw a fall from 2,400 to 1,534, while in Wales numbers had more than halved from 504 to 243. Scotland was down from 759 to 421 while Northern Ireland dropped from 95 to 84.  Campaigners say the problem leaves people with nowhere to go when they need to go and it is affecting everyone from outdoor workers such as builders as well as pregnant women and parents with children. Toilets that can be easily found and used are essential for the elderly and disabled. And with one in five people above 40 suffering from an over-active bladder, the lack of public facilities can make some reluctant to leave their homes due to the risk of being caught short. It is not a legal requirement to provide public lavatories and so when councils aren't feeling flush, toilet blocks are often targeted first when it comes to cuts. A typical toilet block is estimated to cost between &pound12,000 to &pound15,000 a year to maintain. But Domestos believes that clean, safe toilets should be within everyone’s reach. That is why it is launching the nationwide Use Our Loos initiative to tackle the demise and unlock loos in local coffee shops, cafes, restaurants and bars across Britain’s towns, cities and villages.  The scheme is urging local shops and businesses to sign up, throw open their cubicles and make their toilets available to non-customers. As part of the initiative, Domestos is also partnering with The Great British Public Toilet Map – an interactive street map that shows users where their nearest public toilet is and which businesses have signed up to the scheme. The map will be regularly updated as new businesses join. Domestos also plays a role in the Unilever Sustainable Living Plan’s aim to get 25 million people across the world access to a clean and safe toilet by 2020. Domestos has partnered with Unicef, the world’s leading children’s organisa&shytion, since 2012 and has already helped 10 million people around the world get cleaner, safer toilets.  Raymond Martin of the British Toilet Association which campaigns for better public facilities, has praised the initiative, saying it will increase visitors to Britain’s high streets. He says : “As human beings we all have to eat, drink, sleep, breathe and go to the toilet,” he said. “Having access to a clean hygienic toilet is absolutely vital for our everyday life and activity. Rebecca Light, Domestos Senior Brand Manager, says: “In the UK the problem is locating a public toilet. An estimated 2.3 billion people worldwide lack access to clean, safe sanitation. This comes with significant health risks, including diarrhoea, which kills one child every two minutes. It’s vital we change this – and quickly.”

title: horrified dad pulls metal coil
story: NewsHorrified dad pulls METAL COIL from three-year-old son's throat - after he chokes on crispsEXCLUSIVE Preston Green was eating cheese and onion Wheat Crunchies when he approached his parents Adam and Chelsea, from Market Harborough in Leicesterhsire, complaining something was trapped in his throatShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByAbigail O'Leary21:02, 16 AUG 2018Updated21:03, 16 AUG 2018NewsPreston approached his parents gagging on the spring which was stuck in his throat (Image: Adam Green)Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA horrified dad pulled a two-inch METAL COIL from his three-year-old son's throat after he began choking on crisps. Preston Green was eating cheese and onion Wheat Crunchies when he approached his parents Adam and Chelsea, from Market Harborough in Leicestershire, gagging and complaining something was trapped in his throat. In a desperate rush to save his son’s life, panic-stricken Adam, 26, smacked Preston on the back before a silver object, around two inches long, shot out of his mouth. Adam and 24-year-old Chelsea were horrified when they realised their son had been choking on a spring - which they claim came from the crisp packet.  Describing the horrific ordeal which occurred at their family home on Wednesday, Adam told the : We always buy the Wheat Crunchies because they are the boys’ favourite crisps. “We’d bought a multi-pack from Home Bargains in Kettering and Preston asked for a packet so I grabbed a bag to give to him. “Minutes after he started eating them, he runs up to us and starts complaining something was in his throat - he was gagging and choking.” The horrified parents, who also have son Leyton, aged five, reacted instantly, realising something was trapped Preston's airway.  Adam added: “I smacked him on the back and got it out. It was part of a crisp, but wrapped around it was this spring. “It was the size of the Wheat Crunchie - about two inches long I would say.” Adam said Preston went on to complain of pain in his teeth after the traumatic ordeal, likely caused by the spring which he had unknowingly bitten down on. The dad added: It was frightening, but thankfully nothing really serious happened, and Preston is OK, apart from complaining about pain in his teeth. Adam took pictures of the spring and contacted manufacturer KP Snacks, revealing how they had gone through one of every parent's worst nightmares - witnessing their child choking on a piece of food.

title: meghan markle very sweet habit
story: NewsMeghan Markle has a very sweet hobby - and Princess Diana used to love doing the same thingMeghan Markle enjoys spending time completing a rather lovely old school task and it turns out Diana was also a big advocate of doing it tooShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByCourtney PochinAudience Writer10:39, 17 AUG 2018Updated10:41, 17 AUG 2018NewsMeghan has a sweet habit - and Diana used to do it as well (Image: AFP)Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email As the wife of a royal, Meghan Markle will often be compared to those who have come before her - from Kate Middleton to Sarah Ferguson.   But one person that she may be compared to more often than not is her husband's late mum, Princess Diana .   The people's princess remains a firm favourite with fans of the royal family and it is wonderful to see sweet similarities between the two.  Most recently it's come to light that the pair have shared the same thoughtful hobby.   In a post on her old lifestyle blog, The Tig , Meghan went into detail about her love of throwback things - especially the practice of handwriting letters, something Diana also took the time to do.   The former Suits star wrote: Amongst the throwback things that I love (a ’62 porsche speedster &agrave la Dylan McKay in 90210, a bevy of Vargas girls, a Busby Berkeley film, or cooking over a charcoal grill), what trumps all is my love of writing (and receiving) a handwritten note.  She adds that she absolutely adores getting mail. I absolutely relish it. I know my mailman's name, I race to the door when the mail comes (usually just fliers or bills), but I always hold out hope there will be a letter. A sweet letter. And that I will have the tactile experience of un-creasing the paper, reciting the words, and holding someone's thoughts in my hands.   And according to author Andrew Morton , who wrote an authorised biography for Diana, Meghan's late mother-in-law also got a kick out of handwritten letters and was determined to send thank-you cards to as many people as possible.   He notes in particular, that after her grand wedding to Prince Charles in 1981, Diana sat down to answer many of the 47,000 letters of congratulation and 10,000 gifts which the wedding generated.  Though she did have the help of staff to complete this gigantic task. Personal letters from the princess are considered extremely valuable today, with some selling at auctions for thousands of pounds.

title: mum breastfeeding four week old
story: NewsMum breastfeeding four-week-old baby repeatedly stabbed by partner who left knife embedded in her chestWARNING - GRAPHIC IMAGES: Timothy Philpott had started the attack on his partner as she was feeding their four-week-old son in Cannock, StaffordshireShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByTom DavidsonOnline Reporter13:00, 17 AUG 2018Updated16:01, 17 AUG 2018NewsTimothy Philpott, 29, has been jailed for 12 years for attempted murder (Image: Staffs Police)Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A mum-of-two was breastfeeding her four-week-old baby when her partner launched a savage attack upon her.  Timothy Philpott stabbed her several times in the chest and her life was only saved by concerned neighbours who heard her screams and knocked on the door of the home in Cannock, Staffordshire. The victim told police how she had argued with Philpott, 29, in the early hours of February 19 after he accused her of having an affair. The Express and Star report that Philpott was paranoid his partner was seeing someone who lived across the road. At first the thug had punched and kicked his partner and when she told him he would not be able to see his children he replied: I may as well kill you. I'll stab you, and fetched a carving knife from the kitchen.   A neighbour told Stafford Crown Court they’d heard the victim shout shortly before 2am: “Help me, help me, he’s trying to kill me.”  With his savage attack stopped by the neighbours Philpott left the knife embedded in the victim's chest and fled the scene with police called. Officers entering the property found the victim, aged 26 at the time of the incident, on a sofa with a knife blade protruding from her chest. There was blood on the walls and all over her hair and body. They were shining a torch into a coal shed at the rear of a property nearby when they heard a sound in the garden.  They saw a man matching Philpott's description and shouted for him to get on the floor warning him they had a Taser. They handcuffed and arrested him. In a police interview Philpott told detectives he had argued with his partner and had only realised the extent of the assault when there was banging at the door and he ‘snapped out of his red mist.’ Philpott was sentenced to 12 years in jail with a further four years on licence. He pleaded guilty on May 22. The victim underwent emergency surgery at the Queen Elizabeth Hospital in Birmingham, having the knife removed from her chest by surgeons. She is still receiving treatment for a hand injury as she severed tendons when she tried to take hold of the knife, Staffordshire Police said in a statement.

title: muslim woman rejected job after
story: NewsMuslim woman rejected for job after not shaking man's hand during interview awarded £3,000 in compensationFarah Alhajeh, 24, was a candidate for a job as an interpreter but she was told to leave after she told the man she could not shake his handShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByElaine McCahill12:41, 17 AUG 2018Updated13:21, 17 AUG 2018News (Image: COPYRIGHT holder or controlled list of names)Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA Muslim woman who was rejected from a job after not shaking a male interviewer's hand has been awarded over &pound3,000 in compensation. Farah Alhajeh, 24, was a candidate for a job as an interpreter but she was told to leave after telling the male interviewer she could not shake his hand.  Instead of shaking hands, Farah had greeted the man by placing a hand over her heart which is a common custom in the Muslim community. However, Farah claims that as soon as this happened she was told to leave the office in Stockholm and her interview was over.  Speaking to SVT, Farah said: As soon as I got into the lift I started crying. It had never happened to me before - it didn't feel good at all. It was awful. Farah lodged a case with the discrimination ombudsman in Sweden who took the company to court. She won the case and was awarded &pound3,420 in compensation. The ombudsman’s office said the decision had taken into account the employer’s interests, the individual’s right to bodily integrity, and the importance of the state to maintain protection for religious freedom.  Speaking to the BBC, Farah said: I believe in God, which is very rare in Sweden…and I should be able to do that and be accepted as long as I’m not hurting anyone. In my country, you cannot treat women and men differently. I respect that. That’s why I don’t have any physical contact with men or with women.

title: oil gas industry needs wake
story: NewsEx-GCHQ director warns oil and gas industry 'needs to wake up to cyber threat risk'Brian Lord OBE has warned an attack on infrastructure could cause 'unrest across the world' if it is successfulShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByJack Peat15:52, 17 AUG 2018Updated15:54, 17 AUG 2018NewsGCHQ headquarters in Gloucestershire (Image: PA)Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email The oil and gas industry needs to wake up to the cyber threat posed by hostile states, the former Deputy Director of GCHQ has warned.  Brian Lord OBE says a successful attack on its infrastructure could cause “unprecedented damage” and “unrest across the world”. With a complex ecosystem of computation, networking, and physical operational processes spread around the world the industry has a large attack surface with many attack vectors. A typical large oil and gas company uses half a million processors just for oil and gas reservoir simulation and stores petabytes of sensitive and competitive field data as well as sharing and drilling and production control systems across geographies, fields, vendors, service providers, and partners.  The topic will be high on the agenda for industry leaders at this year’s ADIPEC conference in Abu Dhabi. Lord says: “The oil and gas industry is the second most susceptible to cyber-attacks, with the potential to cause unprecedented damage and unrest across the world. “The primary cyber threat to oil and gas infrastructure comes from hostile states who are developing disruptive capabilities in order to deliver power projection for their own long term geo-political and politico-military ends. “Such is the severity of a threat from a relatively small disruptive attack at the right part of an unprepared oil &amp gas system, the issue will be a key topic at this year’s ADIPEC conference, the premier global energy forum for oil &amp gas experts, where industry leaders will be sharing best practice and new developments in order to ensure they always remain one step ahead.”

title: prince georges first day school
story: NewsWhy Prince George's first day at school will be very different this yearPrince George will be starting his second year at Thomas's in Battersea next monthShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByZoe ForseyActing Audience Editor14:00, 17 AUG 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay nowGet daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailParents across the country are making the most of their final few weeks of quality time with the kids before they go back to school, while also secretly counting down the days. Like lots of other little boys and girls, Prince George will be getting ready to start his second year at school in September.  The little royal, who is third in line to the throne, will be going into Year 1 at Thomas's Battersea, a &pound17,604-a-year private school , in south west London.  But George will have a very different first day of term to last year.  Last year when he walked into the school George was met by a group of photographers ready to capture the important milestone. He looked very nervous as he walked through the playground, and was holding his dad's hand, before being greeted by the head of the Lower School, Helen Haslem. When Princes William and Harry started school they faced a huge group of photographers, but the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge only invited a few chosen members of the press to their son's special day. However this year it's unlikely any media will be invited to photograph him arriving for the start of term, as it's normally only done for a young royal's first day at a new school.  The royal family and the media have an agreement which allowed the royal royals to enjoy their education in private. And that won't be the only thing which could be different this year, and there's also a good chance Kate will drop George off at school for his first day this time. Last year, she was too unwell to take him as she was suffering from extreme morning sickness early on in her pregnancy with Prince Louis.

title: teacher stunned find burglar neighbour
story: NewsTeacher stunned to find burglar is her NEIGHBOUR... after she spots him wearing Superdry jacket from CCTVVictim Zoe Bloodworth was speaking to neighbour Ross Peters when she realised he was wearing the same jacketShare&nbspByLouie Smith16:11, 17 AUG 2018NewsRoss Peters was spotted in the same jacket that he wore to burgle Zoe Bloodworth's house (Image: SWNS- Cambridge)Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA teacher realised her neighbour was behind a &pound7,000 break-in at her home after recognising his Superdry jacket on CCTV. Zoe Bloodworth, 32, turned detective after raiders wrecked her home and stole her late grandmother's treasured jewelery. The following day she stopped neighbour Ross Peters, 41, in the street to ask him if he'd seen anyone acting suspiciously in the area. While they chatted Zoe realised his zip-up was an identical match to the one worn by the 'lookout man' filmed during the crime. Police were called in and Peters has now been jailed. Assistant primary school headteacher Zoe said: It actually clicked as he was walking towards me - I didn't let him know I knew because he is a dangerous man. He was wearing the same Superdry jacket. There was no doubt it was him. When we were talking he acted completely like he hadn't heard anything and said 'let me take your number if I hear anything I will call you'. He looked me in the eyes, shook his head and told me he knew nothing. There was no remorse. At Luton Crown Court last week Peters was jailed for 27 months for his part in the burglary, which took place in January this year. Zoe returned to her trashed home and discovered &pound7,000 worth of sentimental items had been taken. This included jewellery left to her by her late grandmother, who died last year. CCTV outside her home in Kempston, Beds., showed Peters lurking outside for 45 minutes as 'lookout' while another unknown man went inside and carried out the raid. Zoe added: Ross was someone I would have waved to as I drove past or I would have said ‘Hi’ if he had walked past me in the street.

title: tesco security guard unconscious 12
story: NewsTesco security guard unconscious for 12 hours after being headbutted by shopper in row over 10p plastic bagThe dad-of-three from Gorton in Manchester was left in hospital and told he will be scarred after the Friday night attackShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsBySteve Robson15:42, 17 AUG 2018Updated15:43, 17 AUG 2018NewsTesco in Gorton, Greater Manchester (Image: Manchester Evening News)Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A Tesco security guard was headbutted and left unconscious for more than 12 hours after being headbutted by a shopper in a row over a 10p plastic bag.  The 55-year-old dad was on duty overnight at the supermarket in Gorton, Manchester last Friday when he was the victim of the horrific unprovoked attack.  The dad-of-three from Gorton told the Manchester Evening News : I saw on the camera that he had not paid for a bag.  “I just told him ‘you have not paid for the bag’. “He went out and then came back. I just see this big guy walk towards me. And then he headbutted and punched me. “The only thing I remember him saying is ‘touch me, touch me’.”  The force of the headbutt knocked the guard immediately unconscious, causing him to fall backwards onto his head. The attacker, who is believed to been in the store with his partner and two young children, then fled the scene. Police cordoned off the store for several hours after the appalling attack at around 1.10am on Saturday as they gathered CCTV evidence and interviewed witnesses. The victim was rushed to hospital where it was discovered his nose was broken and he was told he would be left permanently scarred. He has since been discharged but spent the next day recovering when he should have been celebrating his 25th wedding anniversary with his wife. “The doctor said it could have been very serious, it could have been a life issue,” he said. “I’m in pain. I can’t sleep, they have given me morphine. I feel afraid, like anyone might attack me. “I don’t understand - I don’t know him. Why would someone do this? “I was not confronting him - I’m easygoing. Most people they only love me, because I work in Tesco and I’m a Christian.” A report of the assault prompted an outpouring of anger in the Gorton community.  In a heartfelt post on Facebook , the victim’s son said he forgives his dad’s attacker but called on him to hand himself in and apologise.

title: girl 16 pushed 60ft bridge
story: NewsGirl, 16, pushed off 60ft bridge despite saying "no" wants pal who nearly killed her to be jailedTerrified Jordan Holgerson plunged dozens of feet into a river after being shoved off the bridge in Washington state, US, by pal Taylor SmithShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsBySophie Evans08:35, 17 AUG 2018Updated09:36, 17 AUG 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay nowGet daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA 16-year-old girl who was pushed off a 60ft bridge despite saying no wants the friend who nearly killed her to be jailed. Jordan Holgerson was sent plunging into a river after being shoved off the bridge in Washington state, US, by pal Taylor Smith. Despite suffering serious injuries in the plunge, including six broken ribs, she initially didn't really want Taylor to get into trouble.  But now, she says she wants the 18-year-old to serve some jail time.   Well at first I didn't really want Taylor to get in trouble, Jordan, who also sustained two punctured lungs and bruising, told NBC News .   But now that I've thought about it more, I'm kind of wanting her to sit in jail and think about at least what she did. She added: I'm in a lot of pain. In the mornings it's the worst, like it hurts to breathe. My side hurts. My shoulder hurts. I can't even get up. Dramatic video footage captured Jordan falling dozens of feet from the bridge in Moulton Falls Regional Park, Yacolt, last Tuesday. The teenager could be seen standing nervously at the edge of the structure, before her pal, later identified as Taylor, pushed her from behind. Surrounded by friends, she was reportedly heard saying no twice, before plunging into the Lewis River. She landed with a 'belly flop'.  Cops have investigated the incident and have passed the case to Clark County prosecutors, who are said to be considering charges. Taylor has reportedly been co-operating with investigators.  In an earlier text to NBC News, she said she had repeatedly apologised to Jordan and that she feels really bad about what happened.  She also said she had been receiving threats. However, in her latest interview, Jordan said her pal's apology doesn't help her 'madness' that she almost died and the rest of her summer is gone. The teenager had gone to the bridge with friends last week. It is thought she had initially wanted to jump off the bridge, but ended up getting scared because of its height and told her pals no.  However, before she could come down, she was shoved into the water.  In a previous interview with Mail Online , Jordan's aunt Kristie Morgan said her niece was suffering physically and emotionally, having left hospital.  She said she was struggling to breathe and experiencing panic attacks. But despite the pain, she claimed the teenager didn't want 'revenge'. Speaking before Jordan's comments about jail, she said: Jordan is truly the sweetest girl in the world. She doesn't wish to seek revenge on her friend. But in my opinion her friend needs to learn a lesson.  Jordan sister, Vanessa, spoke to KOIN in Canada shortly after the incident.   I think she [the friend] tried to do it jokingly and didn't think what could have happened, Vanessa said. You don't really play around at 60 feet. The footage of the incident was posted on YouTube last week. As Jordan fell, her arms and legs could be seen flailing helplessly in the air. Ashley Mahree, who recorded the video and posted it on the site, wrote in the description: “This could have easily taken a life, and I think this girl needs to be held accountable in some way. She added: The person that pushed her should go to jail. Although a sign at the site prohibits jumping and diving into the water, the bridge is popular among adrenaline junkies.

title: mum who lost two children
story: NewsMum's heartbreaking wish her daughter's death would be 'as beautiful' as her son's as she loses second child in eight monthsEXCLUSIVE: Stefanie Boyce, whose little girl Brooklyn died last week, found herself asking: 'I wonder if my daughter's death will be as beautiful as my son's?'"Share&nbsp&nbspCommentsBySophie Evans09:01, 17 AUG 2018Updated12:59, 17 AUG 2018NewsStefanie says Jayden and Brooklyn, both pictured, could be laughing together in Heaven (Image: Stefanie Boyce)Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA mum who has lost two children in under a year has revealed her heartbreaking fear that her little girl's death 'wouldn't be as beautiful' as her big brother's. Stefanie Boyce looked on with profound honour as her beautiful nine-year-old daughter, Brooklyn, took her final breath last week after battling a rare condition. Just eight months earlier, she had watched her 11-year-old son, Jayden - Brooklyn's beloved older brother - pass away peacefully as he lay between her and her husband. The siblings had both lived courageously with the same rare and terminal disorder. And as Brooklyn neared the end of her short life, Stefanie found herself asking an unimaginable question that no mum or dad should ever be faced with. What parent has to think these thoughts, 'I wonder if my daughter's death will be as beautiful as my son's?', said the 37-year-old writer, from Illinois, US.  Referring to Brooklyn as 'B' and Jayden as 'J', she added: My greatest fear was B’s passing would be sudden and tragic. A seizure. A morning I’d find her not breathing. Some way that I couldn’t say good-bye. Some way not as holy or sacred as Jayden’s. But since her daughter's death, Stefanie has experienced a form of peace, knowing her two brave children are together again, playing in Heaven. B is probably dragging him around Heaven giving him the tour even though J knows his way around, she said in an emotional tribute to the pair. And I bet J is chuckling and going along with it as she does. It was on Monday, August 6, that Brooklyn received her crown of life, surrounded by her loved ones, including her dad, Justin, 38, and six-year-old sister, Ellie.  Also known as Beeba, the youngster had a contagious laugh and lit up every room with her personality - which was as big as her beautiful blonde hair. The same day of the week, on November 13 last year, her brother and best pal Jayden had gained his own crown, while lying peacefully between their parents. A gentle little boy who had a vibrant smile for everyone, he had loved dancing with his mum, playing with his dad and holding hands with Brooklyn and Ellie. Brooklyn and Jayden had both been 'brave warriors' against Sanfilippo Syndrome, a regressive metabolic disorder that affects around one in 70,000 children. Youngsters with the condition progress for a couple of years, before slowly losing the ability to walk, talk and eat. They typically pass away before they reach 20.  In Stefanie's tribute, which she gave  permission to share, she described how her and husband Justin's routine has all disappeared in one breath. We are no longer a special needs family, said the mum, whose youngest, Ellie, does not have the genetic disease. Our membership to the club got revoked. Expired. And although we never wanted to join, once we did, we didn’t want to leave. Beauty is found in its members. God is found in its meetings. Don’t get me wrong, we will stay connected as honorary members, but honorary none the less. But she added that there’s a peace now that comes as I envision J and B together. Maybe they’re laughing together because B just had to pass on the 6 and J on the 13, so they could share the Monday, she said.  But in true Beeba fashion, her Monday would be first. She concluded: I always wondered why two, but not anymore. Although their lives were short, Brooklyn and Jayden both helped to raise awareness of Sanfilippo Syndrome and the desperate need to find a cure. An obituary for Brooklyn describes how the little girl navigated the condition with strength, grace, and a smile as genuine as they come. She did so while impacting the lives of others. On the day of her daughter's death, Stefanie said it was her profound honour to have watched the youngster take her first and her last breath. Mourning and sadness feel just as right as joy. Brooklyn, you have brought joy to our life and to every life that has ever been touched by yours, she said.  Even in your last few breaths you made me smile in my tears. May I always strive to live as beautifully as you have. She added that she would be forever looking for her sweet girl. The day after Brooklyn's passing, Stefanie and Justin marked their 14th wedding anniversary. They spent part of it at a funeral home, planning their daughter's funeral. Brooklyn's life will be celebrated at Immanuel Church in Gurnee later this month. Although she and Jayden had suffered from Sanfilippo, the syndrome was not all of them and they didn't allow it to stop them from smiling and having fun. Their parents say their legacies will last for an eternity.  Stefanie's full tribute Together. There’s a weird feeling I have that my grief feels complete. There had been an anticipation of having to do this again and fear of what it would be like. My greatest fear was B’s passing would be sudden and tragic. A seizure. A morning I’d find her not breathing. Some way that I couldn’t say good-bye. Some way not as holy or sacred as Jayden’s. What parent has to think these thoughts, “I wonder if my daughter’s death will be as beautiful as my son’s?” I do. But, I’m not the only one. There was an incompleteness to my grief. Maybe that sounds wrong but it isn’t meant to. I certainly would have chosen another day of anticipation if it meant I could have B. It’s just J and B were always, J&ampB. A package deal. It was always hard to separate them, even google photo gets it wrong. Of course they were individuals, too. J was sweet, B was spicy. J was patient, B was ...me. J was a runner, B was a singer.

story: NewsSatanic temple unveils statue of goat god 'Baphomet' outside US government buildingThe striking statue was part of a rally outside the state's seat of government in protest at a Ten Commandments monument already installed in the groundsShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByAmy Coles14:47, 17 AUG 2018Updated14:50, 17 AUG 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay nowGet daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailSatanic worshippers have celebrated the unveiling of a demonic statue of a goat-headed creature with wings outside a government building in the US. Members of the Satanic Temple brought the eight-and-a-half ft tall carving of Baphomet, an occult goat-man hybrid, to the grounds of the Arkansas State Capitol building in Little Rock yesterday. The winged monster sits on a throne emblazoned with a pentagram. Alongside a child gazes adoringly up at the man with the goat head. The striking statue was part of a rally outside the state's seat of government in protest at a Ten Commandments monument already installed in the grounds.  It has now been taken away but the Satanic Temple have filed a lawsuit to have its reinstated in the name of religious pluralism and the First Amendment, KATV news reports. The display prompted counter-protests from Christian activists. The Satanic Church, who have chapters across the globe that campaign for religious freedom, claim they wrote to state legislators in to ask the Baphomet statue be allowed. Speaking at the rally Lucien Greaves, spokesman and co-founder of the Satanic Temple said: “The event is intended to be an inclusive gathering where The Satanic Temple will be celebrating pluralism along with Christian and secular speakers. People of many faiths will come together at the Capitol to reject the Arkansas State Legislature's efforts to privilege one religion over others.

title: woman drives home corpse man
story: NewsWoman drives home with corpse of man who landed in passenger seat after he smashed through windscreenEsteysi 'Stacy' Sanchez, 31, has been convicted of second-degree murder, vehicular manslaughter and hit-and-run after the crash in San DiegoShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByChris MurphyTom DavidsonOnline Reporter09:25, 17 AUG 2018NewsSanchez had drunk at least five alcoholic drinks plus beer before getting behind the wheelGet daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A woman drove home with the corpse of a man she had hit with her car in the passenger seat.  Esteysi 'Stacy' Sanchez, 31, hit the victim so hard his foot was severed and he ended up in the car with her after smashing through the windshield. Investigators and neighbours were equally horrified when they saw the wrecked car parked near her house, with the mutilated corpse still inside. Sanchez is reported to have drunk-driven the car home for more than a mile after the crash on Oceanside in San Diego. She then walked home and changed her clothes, according to evidence heard in court.  Fox 5 reports Sanchez, who sobbed in the dock as she was jailed for 15 years, had been out boozing all night and was heading home when she hit the man at roughly 6am. As her lawyer begged leniency the judge on Wednesday banged her up for 15 years to life in state prison. Sanchez was convicted in April of second-degree murder, gross vehicular manslaughter and hit-and-run in the death of 69- year-old Jack Tenhulzen, reported Fox 5.  Shortly before sentencing Tenhulzen's niece, Lisa Francisco, described her loving uncle and told Sanchez that she broke her heart. At one point, the hearing was interrupted because the defendant was close to collapse as she cried and eventually said: “I’m sorry.” Deputy District Attorney Robert Bruce, prosecuting, had told jurors Sanchez displayed a conscious disregard for human life when she drove drunk and ran over Tenhulzen on a pathway near the state Route 76 bridge the morning of June 27, 2016.  He said the victim went through the windshield and into the passenger seat of her car. The court was told part of one of his legs was severed in the accident and found at the back of the car near the rear window. Tenhulzen was hit so hard that he was ripped out of his trousers and shoes, authorities said.  The news station said it happened after a night of drinking when Sanchez left a hotel room the next morning and was told by a male friend that she was too drunk to drive, Mr Bruce told the jury. In turn, Defence attorney Herb Weston argued Sanchez was tired and fell asleep behind the wheel and rode up on the sidewalk, striking Tenhulzen.

story: NewsAnnoying bedroom habit men can't stand - and the thing women hate more than anythingA new survey by mattress company Leesa has found the things which irritate men and woman the most - and we're all probably guilty of some of themShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByZoe ForseyActing Audience Editor12:06, 17 AUG 2018NewsIt's not always this romantic in the bedroom... (Image: E+)Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThere's nothing better after a long day than climbing into your lovely cosy bed. While some of us will drop straight off, others use that quiet time before bed to wind down with a bit of reading or TV. But sometimes our other halves can ruin these peaceful moments with some very annoying habits.  A new survey by mattress company Leesa has revealed the things which irritate men and woman the most in the bedroom - and we're all probably guilty of some of them.   The top spot is actually the same for both genders, with everyone agreeing the most annoying thing is when your partner starts arguing with you in bed. As well as being REALLY annoying, there's lot of research which shows arguing before bed can actually make the row even worse - so it's better to avoid this at all costs. A partner stealing the covers is another big issue, but it seems women are more bothered by it than men.  Of the 983 people surveyed, 91 per cent of women said it really bothered them compared to 81 per cent of men. Talking on the phone is also a big cause of upset, with 80 per cent of women and 78 per cent of men saying it drives them mad.

title: mum regrets buying hamster kids
story: NewsMum regrets buying hamster for kids after 'little s***' escapes and destroys family carA mum who bought her children a hamster thought she was doing something nice for the family, but things quickly took a bad turnShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByCourtney PochinAudience Writer14:06, 17 AUG 2018Updated14:07, 17 AUG 2018NewsMum bought cute pet for her family - but it quickly turned into a nightmare (Image: Collect Unknown)Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThere's nothing quite like the look on a child's face when they see a cute animal - be it a puppy, kitten or something else. One mum was hoping to create this special moment for her children by getting the family a sweet new pet. Amanda Johnson had been thinking about buying a hamster for a while, but on August 14 she finally took the plunge and headed to the pet shop. She selected the most active and fun fluffy hamster the store had, before heading home to surprise her family. But things didn't quite go to plan.  On the 35-minute drive home, Amanda felt something brush her leg. She chose to ignore it. Then it happened again and she caught a glimpse of the little hamster, sitting behind the clutch pedal. The fluffy pet had managed to get out of it's cage, which had been placed in the boot, and was now moving freely about the car! Amanda drove the rest of the way cautiously, unable to stop and search at the side of the road.  Once home she desperately looked for the family's new pet, to no avail.  In a post on Facebook, which has been shared over 5,000 times, she explained what happened next.  Get home, jumped out and had the last glimpse of the orange fur ball as it burrowed its way behind the pedals. All evening I checked the car every ten minutes trying to entice the thing out - nothing. Anyway, this morning I was first out the door to check of any sign and it’s eaten its way through the passenger seatbelt of my car.  I’ve been to four garages and they have told me the damage to foamy parts of the car including under the seats is extensive and it’s only been 24 hours! We have had no luck in finding it! This could only happen to me! Ask me how much I’m loving life right now!!!!!! Following this initial post, Amanda shared updates on the hilarious situation over the next few days. On day three of having the hamster, she took the car to the garage where mechanics informed her that the damage the pet was causing would result in hours and hours of labour and diagnostics.  She also discovered the passenger door airbag had been destroyed. A friend suggested she try vacuuming the car to lure the hamster out - or lay humane traps, so she headed to the hardware store to buy mouse traps. After four days, she added: This hamster is fast becoming my life! The little s*** has defied eight traps. He has also started nibbling the plastic around the seatbelt area. People on Facebook are loving the story.

title: spanish bull run festival leaves
story: NewsSpanish bull-run festival leaves 11 injured after animal tumbles and rolls over men during downhill chargeWARNING - DISTRESSING CONTENT: A downhill tumble began after one of the animals fell over and crushed a group of young menShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByStephen Jenkins15:56, 17 AUG 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay nowGet daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email Several young men were injured during a bull-running festival when one of the animals fell over and crushed them.  The event, known as the El Pilon de Falces, which translates as the Falces Bull-running Festival, takes place every year in in the town of Falces in the northern Spanish region of Navarre. The run consists of 800 metres along a narrow track involving steep slopes. This year the bulls completed the run in just 58 seconds, but half way down one of the slopes, a bull fell into a group of young men causing several to be crushed.  Despite the dramatic footage there were only light injuries to eight men, although three were treated in hospital , one for bruising, another with a hip injury, and a third with an injured shoulder blade.   They were named as 22-year-old Odei Llanas, Ibai Iribarren, 20, and Adur Otxandorena, 22. Paramedic Jose Manual Merenciano said: The injuries could have been worse if they had been struck in the head. The festival is one of many that take place in small towns and villages in Spain throughout the year where young men in particular are expected to display their courage by running in front of, and alongside, bulls.

title: tragic real life benjamin button
story: NewsReal life 'Benjamin Button' boy looks like wrinkled pensioner aged SIX due to rare genetic diseaseYernar Alibekov was born with a genetic disorder which affects one in 50,000 peopleShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByZoey McDougall13:48, 17 AUG 2018Updated13:52, 17 AUG 2018NewsSix-year-old Yernar Alibekov looks like a wrinkled pensioner due to a rare genetic disease (Image: CEN/@pomosh_ernarchiku)Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThis is the little boy who already looks like a wrinkled pensioner - at the age of SIX - because of a rare genetic disease. Little Yernar Alibekov, from the city of Astana in north-eastern Kazakhstan, was left like this after he was diagnosed with a rare connective tissue disorder known as Ehlers-Danlos syndromes one month after being born. The boys condition was so bad that it left his skin sagging and the first signs came right after he was born with saggy eyelids that left him scratching them all the time.  Just like in the Curious Case of Benjamin Button, Yernar was looking like an old man even as he learned how to walk.    The boy's mother, Zibensa Tulepbergenova, says that even though skin-lifting procedures are officially allowed only as of 18, the administration of the local hospital they came to for help decided to break the rules.  Even though the family could have waited some years to get a free surgery, they decided to spend 112,000 KZT (&pound245) to improve the quality of life of their son. The money was raised by volunteers and friends, as this amount was too high for Yernars family alone.  Experts are skeptical that the surgery will significantly help in Yernars case. Doctor Olga Loseva said: This is a rare disease that happens to one in 50,000. The fact that the boy had surgery won't improve his skin condition if it is saggy it wont change. The only way out is to mitigate consequences of this disease and take great care of him.

title: brechin city line up loan swoop for dundee striker scott
story: Young Dundee striker Cedwyn Scott has been lined up by Brechin City for a possible loan move – though the League One side have Championship competition.It’s not known which second tier side are interested but Brechin have reportedly made an inquiry about the player who set Dundee Colts off on their way to a penalty shootout victory by netting the first spot-kick at Dens on Tuesday night.Scott banged in the goals for the Dark Blues development squad last season as they just missed out on the league title to Hibs.However, the 19-year-old has only made three appearances for the first team and has yet to feature this time round and a stint at the League One side could do the hotshot the world of good.Scott could follow in the footsteps of Craig Wighton who had a brief spell on loan at Glebe Park.Despite being a fresh-faced 17-year-old, he managed two goals in four appearances.Coach Jimmy Boyle was delighted to see his side “stick to their guns” in the Irn-Bru Cup victory over Hibs.Tom Bradbury’s back-post header from Jack Lambert’s cross gave the young Dees the lead before Fraser Murray replied in the first half.The visitors then took the lead as Sean Mackie smashed past goalkeeper Sam Jackson after he’d made a string of saves.Dan Jefferies, though made it a centre-half double for his side, heading in with five minutes left to set up penalties.Jackson made two saves to give Bradbury the chance to send his side through to the second round, which he did emphatically.Coach Jimmy said: “When you look at our team, we’re a lot younger than them. We knew it would be a good game, we know what Hibs are about, they are a very good team.“I enjoyed the way we played, some of the stuff in the first half was excellent but we know they have quality and put us under pressure. I’m pleased we stuck to our guns and we got what we deserved.”There was plenty to be happy about including an impressive display from winger Cammy Dow.Jimmy said: “Sam Jackson did great, he’s a confident big boy and I thought Cammy Dow was excellent – he’s a massive Dundee fan as well, which is great.”The second-round draw is today at 1pm.&nbsp

title: csaba proud of his dundee united players for handling pressure at queen of the south
story: Dundee United’s players might have been feeling the pressure according to boss Csaba Laszlo but he was proud they didn’t show it in their their 2-1 victory at Queen of the South.An impressive first-half display put the Tangerines in a winning position as Sam Stanton and debutant Pavol Safranko gave them a two-goal lead.The second period saw United have to defend their lead as the Doonhamers came at them with Stephen Dobbie knocking in after 67 minutes – Csaba’s men, though, held them at arms length for the rest of the contest and grabbed their first victory of the league season.The manager said: “I am proud of the boys because they did a good job.“We were under pressure because we knew against Dunfermline we lost an important game and now the second game of the season we had to perform and to win.“This was definitely a very good team performance and I am proud of the boys, they worked for each other.“We had a really bad start at home against Dunfermline and I think the players felt there was pressure.“We don’t want to disappoint our fans again and you saw there were a lot of our fans at the game and they celebrated also.“The fans made the noise against Dunfermline that it wasn’t good enough and we heard that.“I said after that Dundee United can play better football and our fans deserved more spirit, more fighting spirit and better results.“That pressure is always there if you have the jersey of Dundee United, if you are the manager of Dundee United, work for Dundee United you are the biggest club in the Championship and everybody wants to beat you.“People think it is easy to win a game, it is not easy – you have to respect the opponent, you have to know in this league it is not always nice football, it is more fighting and desire.“You could see Queen of the South didn’t give up, in the second half they put I don’t know how many balls up front.“I am really pleased with the first-half performance, I am a little bit angry we don’t close the game out but I’m happy with the three points and the performance from the team.”
